pullRequest.body:
In this pull request, we define:
Given a scheme `X` and a point `x : X.carrier`, `AlgebraicGeometry.Scheme.fromSpecStalk X x` is the canonical scheme morphism from `Spec(O_x)` to `X`.

This is helpful for constructing the canonical map from the spectrum of the residue field of a point to the original scheme.

So do we have the map Spec(stalk at x) -> X? We should surely make this first?
Also, I think the file could be called `Stalk.lean` and contain anything related to stalks.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
`h` is a proof so this should be `have` not `let`.

```suggestion
    rw [show iSup U = âŠ¥ by simp only [iSup_eq_bot, implies_true]] at h
```
`rw` can see into all the `congArg` things, you don't need them.
Are we really supposed to write `x : X.toTopCat` and not `x : X`?
Yes! `x : X` is enough!

I think a lot of people will find this docstring unhelpful. Why not say what this definition is mathematically instead? i.e. the map from the stalk at a point to the global sections of the spectrum of the residue field. It is not entirely clear to me that we want this map, it's just a composite of two maps we already have.

In fact, seeing this definition makes me wonder whether you should in fact be defining the map from Spec(O_x) to X, and then defining the map from Spec(k_x) to X as being the composite of this one and the canonical map from Spec(k_x) to Spec(O_x). What do you think? Maybe it would make the construction easier, and we probably want the map from Spec(O_x) anyway.

I think yes. It is better for us to first construct the morphism from Spec(O_x) to X. Today, apart from the final proof for the fact that the induced stalk map is a local ring homomorphism, I managed to construct everything else necessary for formalising the morphism from Spec(O_x) to X. I found that we could actually delete the definition `AlgebraicGeometry.LocallyRingedSpace.StalkToResidueFieldSpecGlobalSectionHom`.
In my new push, I have changed everything into the foundations for the formalisation of the morphism from Spec(O_x) to X.
These should go in `AffineScheme.lean`. The third one could be a simp lemma.

```suggestion
noncomputable def IsAffineOpen.fromSpecStalk {X : Scheme} {U : TopologicalSpace.Opens X}
    (hU : IsAffineOpen U) {x : X} (hxU : x âˆˆ U) :
    Spec (X.stalk x)) âŸ¶ X :=
  Spec.map (X.presheaf.germ âŸ¨x, hxUâŸ©) â‰« hU.fromSpec
```
(same below)

```suggestion
  rfl
```
(it's a bit quicker and does the same thing)

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
canonical scheme morphism from `Spec(O_x)` to `X`.
```

```suggestion
A morphism from `Spec(O_x)` to `X`, which is defined with the help of an affine open
```

```suggestion
If `x` is a point of `X`, this is the canonical scheme morphism from `Spec(O_x)` to `X`.
```

```suggestion
@[simp, reassoc]
```
This adds `simp` to the assoc lemma as well.
According to [this](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/reassoc.20and.20simp/near/449310703) it's actually ` @[reassoc (attr := simp)]`.
Can you provide a simp lemma `hU.fromSpecStalk hxU = X.fromSpecStalk x`?
Also, it would be nice to show that this commutes with `stalkSpecializes` or `PresheafedSpace.stalkMap`, but they can come in a later PR.

```suggestion
noncomputable def Scheme.fromSpecStalk (X : Scheme) (x : X) :
```

According to [this post](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/reassoc.20and.20simp/near/449310703) this should be `@[reassoc (attr := simp)]`, and there is an explanation there about how to check that this works.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - Feat(AlgebraicGeometry/FromSpecStalk): Given a scheme `X` and a point `x : X`, the canonical scheme morphism from `Spec(O_x)` to `X`.
